The William Blake Archive www.blakearchive.org is pleased to announce that it has received a two-year Preservation and Access Grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities. The editors and staff are most grateful for the support it provides as we begin to expand the Archive over the next few years to include Blake's drawings, paintings, and engravings.
We are also very pleased to announce the publication of new electronic editions of The Marriage of Heaven and Hell Copies H and I, both in the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge, England. Printed in 1790 and 1827 respectively, they join copies of Marriage in the Archive from other printings: Copies C (1790), D (1795), and F (c. 1794). Copy G, from a c. 1818 printing, and Copy K (Plates 21-24) and Copies L and M (separate printings of "A Song of Liberty") from a 1790 printing are forthcoming.
The electronic editions have newly edited SGML-encoded texts and new images scanned and color-corrected from first-generation 4 x 5 inch transparencies; texts and images are fully searchable and supported by the Inote and ImageSizer applications described in our previous updates.
With the publication of these two titles, the Archive now contains fully searchable and scalable electronic editions of 41 copies of 18 of Blake's 19 illuminated books in the context of full bibliographic information about each work, careful diplomatic transcriptions of all texts, detailed descriptions of all images, and extensive bibliographies. They also join our searchable SGML-encoded electronic edition of David V. Erdman's Complete Poetry and Prose of William Blake. With the forthcoming publication of Jerusalem Copy E, the Archive will contain at least one copy of each of Blake's works in illuminated printing and multiple copies of most.
Marriage Copy H, perhaps the most illuminated of Blake's illuminated books, appears initially to have relied on colored inks rather than watercolor washes for its coloring. It was produced with Copy B in 1790, with plates printed in various shades of red, olive, and green inks on both sides of the leaves. The impressions forming Copy B (Bodleian Library, Oxford University) are uncolored, and those forming Copy H may also have been left in this state originally. But Copy H was sold to the painter John Linnell, Blake's young patron, in 1821 for two pounds and two shillings (less than half of what he was asking for books of similar size and number of pages), and apparently at that time Blake extensively reworked the pages by coloring the illustrations, adding gold leaf (e.g., title page), streaking the background of the texts in yellows and blues, and, what is most unusual, going over the texts in various colored inks, letter by letter, line by line. The results are pages among the most colorful that Blake ever produced and texts among the most challenging editorially, with many key words and phrases visually highlighted (e.g., "Contraries" and "Human existence" of Plate 3 set off by dark ink in lines rewritten in red ink). Such detailed refinishing also resulted in a book with stylistic features characteristic of productions both early (facing pages and plates printed without borders) and late (elaborate coloring and page numbers).
One stylistic element characteristic of illuminated books produced c. 1818 and later is the frameline, usually one thin line in red or black ink drawn a few centimeters around the image. Copy H has no framelines, probably because they would prove visually jarring for pages that face one another. But they are used to superb effect in Marriage Copy I, where they set off each page as a miniature painting. Copy I, printed and colored in 1827 for Thomas Wainewright, was one of the last illuminated books produced by Blake. It was printed in orangish-red ink on one side of J. Whatman paper dated 1825, numbered 1-27, and finished in gold, watercolors, and pen and ink to match Wainewright's copy of Songs (Copy X). It was produced in the same style Blake used in c. 1818, 1821-22, and 1825-26. Works from these sessions include The Book of Thel Copy O and Songs of Innocence and of Experience Copies Z and AA, which are in the Archive, and The Marriage of Heaven and Hell Copy G, Jerusalem Copy E, America, a Prophecy Copy O, Europe, a Prophecy Copy K, and Visions of the Daughters of Albion Copy P, all of which will enter the Archive within the year. Printing plates in full (i.e., with their plate borders), a feature of this late production style, can make pages appear slightly larger and introduce compositional elements missing in copies printed earlier. For Marriage Copy I, as well as Copy G, the inclusion of the plate borders introduced the outer lines forming rocks and cavern shapes on Plates 10, 11, 15, and 20, images named in the text but pictured only in these last two copies.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The bottom two-thirds of the plate seems to be beneath the ground level of the natural world, which occupies the top one-third. Near the bottom of the plate, beneath the word "hell" (line 7), a nude couple, perhaps (though not distinctly) female (left) and male (right), kiss while embracing. They are probably intended to represent the "marriage" of "heaven" and "hell" (lines 3, 5, 7). The figure on the right, facing left with body twisted forward, is stretched out horizontally on a cloud; the figure on the left, facing right but with the body seen from behind, hovers above a burst of flames. Above them several other figures, mostly embracing couples, fly upward between the flames on the left and the clouds (of smoke?) on the right. Above them in turn, at ground level, in a landscape of leafless arching trees whose roots are visible below ground, as if seen in cross-section, a couple strolls on the left and a single figure kneels beside another figure lying on the ground. There appears to be the edge of a cliff far left. Birds fly in the sky at the top of the plate. The dark coloring of the cloudy sky suggests a storm, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: At the ground level of what may be heaven or the natural world, leafless trees, several on each side with one in the center, arch overhead, involving the words "marriage of" in the title (lines 3-4). The dark coloring of the cloudy sky suggests a storm, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.
The far left side of the ground descends vertiginously, thereby creating a cliff-like escarpment.

At ground level on the left, two figures of uncertain gender walk together. The figure on the right, who may be gowned, has his or her left arm is raised at 45 degrees.
At ground level on the right, a nude figure, probably male, kneels, arms bent upward to his face, perhaps in prayer or grief, and facing another figure lying on the ground.
At ground level on the right, a figure lies on his or her left side on the ground, legs drawn up and right arm wrapped around the head. The figure's head probably faces down.

A group of perhaps ten or twelve nude figures, including four embracing couples, fly diagonally upward to the right, toward ground level. One figure in the couple right of "and" (line 6) in the text holds the hand of a small figure, perhaps a child.
Flames, representing hell, burst from the lower left side of the plate and extend diagonally almost to the right margin.
Clouds, possibly of smoke, billow from the lower right side of the plate, representing heaven.

The last letter of "MARRIAGE" (line 3) in the text grows into a vine with at least one loop. It is intertwined with the trees to the right. The penultimate letter grows into two vines, the lower perhaps bearing a leaf, the upper one a loop. Other letters also sprout loopy vines.
The last letter of "and" (line 6) in the text grows into a vine circling around the word.

Near the bottom of the plate, beneath the word "hell" (line 7), a nude couple kiss while embracing. The figure on the left, possibly female and facing right but with her body seen from behind, lies horizontally in a burst of flames. She probably represents "hell" (line 7) in the "marriage" (line 3) and is in that sense a devil.

The figure on the right, indeterminately male or female, lies horizontally on a cloud (of smoke?)—facing to the left, but with the body facing forward. The figure's hair is long. He or she probably represents "heaven" (line 5) in the "marriage" (line 3) and is in that sense an angel.

illustration.illusobjdesc: At top right a female figure in a long swirling gown holds with her left hand to the upper branch of a leafy tree that extends the length of the right margin. With her right hand she seems to hand something, perhaps fruit, down to a second female figure, similarly gowned, who stands alongside the tree. With her legs crossed, she reaches upward with her right arm while supporting herself with her raised left arm around the trunk. At lower left a male (left) and possibly a female (right), both nude, lie on leafy vegetation with the right foot of the man nearly meeting the foot or leg of the female. The figure to the left rests his head on his right hand and has its legs crossed. The female to the right lies with arm outstretched and bent at the elbow. Behind the right figure is the head and upper body of a third figure. Between the two groups of figures is a loopy vine with a few leaves. The colors of the sky suggest sunrise or sunset on the right with rosy clouds above. The scene may represent the "paths of ease" mentioned in the Argument (line 16).

lg.l: Rintrah roars & shakes his fires in the burdend air;
Hungry clouds swag on the deep
Once meek, and in a perilous path,
The just man kept his course along
The vale of death.
Roses are planted where thorns grow,
And on the barren heath
Sing the honey bees.
Then the perilous path was planted;
And a river, and a spring
On every cliff and tomb;
And on the bleached bones
Red clay brought forth.
Till the villain left the paths of ease,
To walk in perilous paths, and drive
The just man into barren climes.
Now the sneaking serpent walks
In mild humility.
And the just man rages in the wilds
Where lions roam.
Rintrah roars & shakes his fires in the
burdend air;
Hungry clouds swag on the deep.

Another vine-like streamer, interrupted by the "i" of "since," decorates the space between lines 2 and 3; line 8 begins, and the final word of line 9 terminates, with further instances of this motif. Below it, two figures, possibly a male and gowned female, stand facing each other and holding hands on a vine-like arabesque. The background tinting suggests sky.

lg.l: As a new heaven is begun, and it is now thir-
-ty-three years since its advent: the Eternal Hell
revives. And lo! Swedenborg is the Angel sitting
at the tomb; his writings are the linen clothes folded
up. Now is the dominion of Edom, & the return of
Adam into Paradise; see Isaiah XXXIV & XXXV Chap:
Without Contraries is no progression. Attraction
and Repulsion, Reason and Energy, Love and
Hate, are necessary to Human existence.
From these contraries spring what the religious call
Good & Evil. Good is the passive that obeys Reason
Evil is the active springing from Energy.
Good is Heaven. Evil is Hell,

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design repeats the strong left-right divisions of the lower title page and the lower design on Plate 3, but now with a landscape divided between water and fire rather than clouds and fire. Perhaps continuing the saga begun at the bottom of Plate 3, a nude male with curly hair hovers against a background of flames. His right ankle is shackled and apparently chained. On the left, running or flying over water, with a sun behind, is a nude figure of indeterminate sex holding a child. One of the color prints of this subject is inscribed by Blake "The Good & Evil Angels" (Butlin nos. 323-24).

component.illusobjdesc: On the left, running or flying over water with left foot foremost, a sun behind, is a nude figure of indeterminate sex, holding a child with his or her left arm. According to Blake's later inscription on a color print, the figure may be a "good angel" ("The Good & Evil Angels," Butlin nos. 323-24).
A nude child or infant, legs spread and arms raised vertically, is held by the figure on the left.

An apparently male nude figure with arms raised horizontally hovers over water against a background of flames. He faces to the left; his hair is curly. His right leg is shackled and apparently chained (insubstantially to the water below?). His eyes appear to be closed, or he may be blind. According to Blake's later inscription on a color print, he may be an "evil angel" ("The Good & Evil Angels," Butlin nos. 323-24).
The right leg of the figure is bound with a shackle; at least two links in a chain descends below the shackle toward the water below.
A sun shines in the background over the water. Radiance and beams of light emanate from it.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Numerous interlinear designs ornament the plate. A heraldic vignette announces "The voice of the Devil" (lines 2-3): three angels blow their trumpets on either side of these lines. To the left of the text, two of the angels—one gowned, the other nude—face up and left; to the right of the text, the third angel, also gowned, mirrors its companions, facing up and right. A looped, vine-like extension grows from the ascender of "all" in line 4. Beside the lone angel on the right, a vine rises from the first letter of "been" in line 4; alternatively, one might interpret the motif as a bird, flying left, whose tail touches the ascender of "been." Its fantastic plume contains a single loop, a feature that continues the vegetative motif of the scene. To the right of the vine or bird ascends a smaller winged creature, either a bird or an insect, and to its left, three leaf-like flags extend from the "d" of "sacred" and the "h" of "have" in line 4. These flags may represent the musical notes of the trumpeters. Below the winged bird or insect, at the end of line 5, are further vegetative swirls (these are human figures in some other copies). Further down, to the right of line 7, a small figure, its body and arms horizontal, flees from a recumbent figure on a leaf. Next to the words "the Soul" in line 10 are seven figures in sundry positions. There may be two huddled figures facing each other. The figure on the right in this group crouches or squats, reaching an arm out to its companion. They are followed by two tiny figures hovering and facing each other. They may be holding hands. The hand-holding figures hover above a vine-like streamer extending from the "M" of "Man" in line 11. Next to this pair, three figures huddle together on some vegetation consisting of leaves and/or tufts of grass. Following the word "Energies" in line 12 are four figures and two animals: the first animal, perhaps a horse, kicks up its back heels. Next to it stand two children holding hands, followed by another hand-holding pair, a child and an adult. The latter extends his left arm horizontally, perhaps pointing to the ox which grazes nearby on a bit of tableland. An ornamental ribbon, most likely vegetative in nature, closes the vignette. Further down the plate, three leaves grow from the "B" of "But" in line 13. A branch with spiky leaves grows from the "e" of "age" in line 17. Following it, an amorphous, horizontal figure hovers above a wispy line, suggesting a cirrus-like cloud. The figure raises its arm, seemingly in an effort to make contact with the adjacent figure, who hovers, legs spread and one arm reaching to the left, above a line of vegetation. To the right, a man walks a small dog on a leash. The forms on each side of the man and dog may be the stumps of trees. Facing left, a lumbering figure, bearded or blindfolded, walks (runs?) in a contorted position, viz., bending forward from the waist with one arm outstretched in front of him. Mimicking his general posture, an anthropomorphic tree arches to the left. Near the margin between lines 18 and 19 stands a small figure, possibly holding a cane. Six or seven figures observe another figure one line down. With legs slightly apart and arms raised, it appears to address its audience. To its back is either a tree with a disproportionally large branch or leaf. Concluding the procession, two horses, the second of which is indicated merely by some faint profile lines, pull a figure in its cart. Background coloring suggests sky, perhaps as a continuation of the major design below the text.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Following the word "Abyss" in line 3 is a vignette that spans nearly the width of the plate. A curved line might be a plant bent almost to the ground. At the end of line 8, a gowned figure hangs suspended from the "g" of "flaming" (line 7). The odd forms in the center of line 7 may be flames, as in some other copies. Poised above the "w" of "walking" in line 16 is a figure with arms raised horizontally and one leg extended backward. At the bottom of the plate, blue coloring and some spiky forms suggest a stormy sea and perhaps a bolt of lightning. Although partly covered with wash, fragments of letters seem to be emerging on the left: most likely "HOW," which begins the devil's question, "How do you know," as written with corroding fires on the sides of the rock and "now percieved by the minds of men" (plte 7, lines 2-5).

lg.l: Prisons are built with stones of Law, Brothels with
bricks of Religion.
The pride of the peacock is the glory of God.
The lust of the goat is the bounty of God.
The wrath of the lion is the wisdom of God.
The nakedness of woman is the work of God.
Excess of sorrow laughs. Excess of joy weeps.
The roaring of lions, the howling of wolves, the raging
of the stormy sea. and the destructive sword. are
portions of eternity too great for the eye of man.
The fox condemns the trap, not himself.
Joys impregnate, Sorrows bring forth.
Let man wear the fell of the lion. woman the fleece of
the sheep.
The bird a nest, the spider a web, man friendship.
The selfish smiling fool. & the sullen frowning fool. shall
be both thought wise. that they may be a rod.
What is now proved was once, only imagin'd.
The rat, the mouse. the fox, the rabbet; watch the roots,
the lion, the tyger. the horse. the elephant, watch
the fruits,
The cistern contains: the fountain overflows
One thought, fills immensity.
Always be ready to speak your mind, and a base man
will avoid you.
Every thing possible to be believ'd is an image of truth.
The eagle never lost so much time. as when he submit-
-ted to learn of the crow.

lg.l: The fox provides for himself, but God provides for the lion.
Think in the morning. Act in the noon, Eat in the even-
-ing, Sleep in the night,
He who has sufferd you to impose on him knows you.
As the plow follows words, so God rewards prayers.
The tygers of wrath are wiser than the horses of in-
Expect poison from the standing water. -struction
You never know what is enough unless you know what is
more than enough.
Listen to the fools reproach! it is a kingly title!
The eyes of fire, the nostrils of air, the mouth of water,
the beard of earth.
The weak in courage is strong in cunning.
The apple tree never asks the beech how he shall grow,
nor the lion, the horse, how he shall take his prey.
The thankful reciever bears a plentiful harvest.
If others had not been foolish, we should be so.
The soul of sweet delight, can never be defil'd,
When thou seest an Eagle, thou seest a portion of Ge-
-nius. lift up thy head!
As the catterpiller chooses the fairest leaves to lay
her eggs on, so the priest lays his curse on
the fairest joys.
To create a little flower is the labour of ages.
Damn, braces: Bless relaxes.
The best wine is the oldest. the best water the newest.
Prayers plow not! Praises reap not!
Joys laugh not! Sorrows weep not!

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude male devil with blue skin and bat wings, pointing to a scroll across his lap, kneels between two seated scribes. A gowned figure (probably male) to the left apparently writes down what he says and a second gowned figure (probably male) to the right looks over his shoulder and copies from the scroll to the tablet in his lap. All three figures are on a grassy island or shore, with dark water in front of them. Behind the central devil is a table or stool covered with something, perhaps a cushion. Spiky vegetation—a plant of some sort—frames the figures on the right; the threatening plant on the left might be a catchfly. The rounded forms far left and right may be clouds or a suggestion of large rocks or a cave's mouth (see Plate 11 in this copy). The coloring of the sky hints at a sunrise or sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Against a sky streaked with a rose-tinted dawn, (left to right) a human sun rises, a human water spout rises, and a maternal earth-goddess nurses an infant in a bed of vegetation or, given the blue coloring, water. These identifications are tentative. The sun-goddess may be a flower-goddess; the personifications appear to change from Copy to copy. The scene is framed, below, by grassy ground, and on the other three sides by the mouth of a cave. The latter finds a textual connection with the "narrow chinks" of a bodily "cavern" (Plate 14, line 21). Perhaps we are to think of the cave formation here as the eye socket of the viewer. Thus, the viewer, not the figures pictured, is inside the cave, a perspective also suggested by the appearance of the sky in the distance.

lg.l: The ancient Poets animated all sensible objects
with Gods or Geniuses, calling them by the names and
adorning them with the properties of woods, rivers,
mountains, lakes, cities, nations, and whatever their
enlarged & numerous senses could percieve.
And particularly they studied the genius of each
city & country. placing it under its mental deity.
Till a system was formed, which some took ad-
vantage of & enslav'd the vulgar by attempting to
realize or abstract the mental deities from their
objects; thus began Priesthood.
Choosing forms of worship from poetic tales.
And at length they pronouncd that the Gods
had orderd such things.
Thus men forgot that All deities reside
in the human breast.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The second line, "A Memorable Fancy," is flanked by interlinear designs. The base of the letter "A" grows into a long, looped vine. Three swirls curve above the vegetation, and a small figure dances(?). Two birds fly above the text (the one on the left partly obscured by gold in this copy). To the right of line 2, a monkey-like figure strides across a vine. Left of line 3, a (grape?) leaf introduces "The Prophets." The plate as a whole is rich with vegetative swirls and lines, which are often vine-like or serpentine, though those above "answer'd" and "saw" in line 8 resonate with the image of outspread wings of soaring birds, such as those found above lines 7 and 9. Some of the vegetative motifs extend from ascenders and descenders of letters. Wedged between the right margin and the word "imposition" at the end of line 7 is a looping vine or possibly a worm. At the beginning of line 8, a snake with open mouth precedes the word "Isaiah." Hovering above text and among swirls, hovering figures appear at the ends of lines 15 and 19. Touches of blue wash in the margins, particularly top right, suggest sky.

lg.l: The Prophets Isaiah and Ezekiel dined with
me, and I asked them how they dared so roundly to
assert. that God spoke to them; and whether they
did not think at the time, that they would be mis-
-understood, & so be the cause of imposition,
Isaiah answer'd. I saw no God, nor heard
any, in a finite organical perception; but my sen-
-ses discover'd the infinite in every thing, and as I
was then perswaded, & remain confirm'd; that the
voice of honest indignation is the voice of God, I
cared not for consequences but wrote.
Then I asked: does a firm perswasion that a
thing is so, make it so?
He replied, All poets believe that it does, &
in ages of imagination this firm perswasion remo
-ved mountains; but many are not capable of a
firm perswasion of any thing.
Then Ezekiel said. The philosophy of the east
taught the first principles of human perception
some nations held one principle for the origin &
some another, we of Israel taught that the Poetic
Genius (as you now call it) was the first principle
and all the others merely derivative, which was the
cause of our despising the Priests & Philosophers

illustration.illusobjdesc: A bluish male body, nude, arms at his sides, extends horizontally across the plate. The color and arrangement suggest that he is dead. Hovering in flames over him is a nude(?), long-haired female figure with her arms raised horizontally. She is at right angles to the male with her head toward the viewer. At least twice Blake color printed the plate, with its text masked (Butlin nos. 260.5, 261.3). His inscription for one of these, "a Flaming Sword / Revolving every way" (E673, K 261), relates the design to the so-called covering cherub, or guardian angel, whom God posted to keep humanity away from the Tree of Life after the expulsion from Eden. The top (rotating) figure in the design would then seem to be a personification of the sword-as-angel who is keeping the dead figure below away from the Tree of Life. Green coloring on the ground below the supine figure hints at grass.

lg.l: The ancient tradition that the world will be con-
-sumed in fire at the end of six thousand years
is true, as I have heard from Hell.
For the cherub with his flaming sword is
hereby commanded to leave his guard at tree of
life, and when he does, the whole creation will
be consumed, and appear infinite. and holy
whereas it now appears finite & corrupt.
This will come to pass by an improvement of
sensual enjoyment.
But first the notion that man has a body
distinct from his soul, is to be expunged; this
I shall do, by printing in the infernal method, by
corrosives, which in Hell are salutary and me-
-dicinal, melting apparent surfaces away, and
displaying the infinite which was hid,
If the doors of perception were cleansed
every thing would appear to man as it is, in-
-finite.
For man has closed himself up, till he sees
all things thro' narrow chinks of his cavern.

lg.l: I was in a Printing house in Hell & saw the
method in which knowledge is transmitted from gene-
-ration to generation.
In the first chamber was a Dragon-Man, clear-
-ing away the rubbish from a caves mouth; within, a
number of Dragons were hollowing the cave,
In the second chamber was a Viper folding round
the rock & the cave, and others adorning it with gold
silver and precious stones.
In the third chamber was an Eagle with wings
and feathers of air, he caused the inside of the cave
to be infinite, around were numbers of Eagle like
men, who built palaces in the immense cliffs.
In the fourth chamber were Lions of flaming fire
raging around & melting the metals into living fluids.
In the fifth chamber were Unnam'd forms, which
cast the metals into the expanse.
There they were reciev'd by Men who occupied
the sixth chamber, and took the forms of books &

illustration.illusobjdesc: The first lines on this plate—"The Giants who formed this world into its sensual existence and now seem to live in it in chains" (lines 2-5)—seem to describe the design, which depicts five gowned human figures sitting in severely contracted positions, all crowded into a dark stone chamber, prison, or cavern. The heads of all except the bearded central figure, who looks out toward the viewer, are down and turned toward the center. Though the limbs of the figures are drawn tightly together as if chained, no chains are in evidence—in line with the sentiment of the text that the giants only "seem" (line 3) to live in chains.

component.illusobjdesc: Five seated figures sit in a chamber, prison, or cave, probably built or cut from stone. In this copy, the walls look man-made, and thus more probably a prison or chamber than a cave.

The gowned figure on the far left sits against a wall, facing toward the center, in a severely contracted position with the visible leg drawn up and head down. The figure probably represents one of the "Giants who formed the world into its sensual existence" (lines 2-3).

The gowned figure second from the left sits with back against the wall in a severely contracted position with legs drawn up and crossed just above the ankle, head down but twisted toward the center, and right foot exposed. He is one of only three figures with face visible, seen in profile. His hair may be curly. The figure probably represents one of the "Giants who formed the world into its sensual existence" (lines 2-3).

The gowned male figure in the center, old and at least partly bald, sits with his back against the wall in a severely contracted position, legs drawn up and crossed, right foot exposed. His arms are raised horizontally to embrace the two figures at his side, right and left. The fingers of both hands appear to be spread apart, although in this copy his right arm and hand appear only as etched outlines obscured by coloring. The figure probably represents one of the "Giants who formed the world into its sensual existence" (lines 2-3). The design, however, closely resembles Blake's several illustrations of the Ugolino episode in Dante's Divine Comedy, and thus this central figure is compositionally related to (albeit not directly identifiable as) Count Ugolino surrounded by his sons in prison.

The gowned figure fourth from the left sits with his right side against the wall, facing the center in a severely contracted position with his one visible leg drawn up and his head down. We see part of his face in profile; his hair appears to be curly. The figure probably represents one of the "Giants who formed the world into its sensual existence" (lines 2-3).

The gowned figure on the right sits with his back against the wall far right, facing the center in a severely contracted position with his one visible leg drawn up and his head down. The figure probably represents one of the "Giants who formed the world into its sensual existence" (lines 2-3).

objnote.p: At the bottom of the plate, in the waves under the leviathan, Blake wrote in white-line etching: "Opposition is True Friendship." Color printing obscured these words completely in Copies E and F, and watercolor finishing made them barely visible in the other colored copies, A, C, D, G-I. In uncolored Copy B, "Friendship" was filled in with ink and did not print legibly.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the waves of a dark and tumultuous sea, Leviathan appears as a coiled, scaly serpent with its head raised vertically, mouth open, teeth visible, tongue extended. Dark clouds frame the image left and right; the one on the left is so solid that it suggests the cave formations on some other plates in this copy (e.g., Plate 11). Blake inscribed one of the two color-printed impressions of the design "O revolving serpent / O the Ocean of Time & Space" (see Butlin no. 260.6 for an uninscribed impression).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Blue washes here and there throughout the plate suggest sky; golden washes variously suggest sky or earth. At the end of line 2, a scrolled shape with wavy lines intersecting its midsection has been seen as a sea creature entangled in the remnants of a net; the scene as a whole is said to illustrate the text that continues from the previous plate, which describes Swedenborg's self-deceptions: he imagines "himself the single / one on earth that ever broke a net" (Plate 21, lines 14-15; Plate 22, line 2). In this copy, the shape seems vegetative or worm-like. Beyond this shape, a hunched figure (possibly holding a book or tablet) sits on a vine. Following "falshoods" in line 5, a figure clad in a billowing garment hovers amidst some vegetation. Below, two elaborate spirals radiate from a common center right of line 9. To the right of "further" in line 12 are several large, vivid leaves. Next to "number" in line 17, three birds soar on extended wings. To the left of the long-tailed bird and below the small, nondescript bird are two swollen vegetable forms. A loop extending above the "h" of "he" at the end of line 18 coincides with the wing of the largest bird. Four figures bound the plate's inscription, "A Memorable Fancy" (line 21), on three sides. The first figure reclines beneath some leaves and branches to the left of the text. The vegetation transforms into loops and squiggles clinging to the margin of the plate. Above the inscription (line 21), a hovering figure, arm(s) extended, seems to reach for a serpent. The four-looped vine growing from the "F" of "Fancy" and the squiggly "y" of the same word continue the serpentine motif. To the right of the text, the third figure of the vignette stands facing right with arms raised at 135 degrees. His head is bent back, and his posture suggests he has just been impaled by the invisible arrow released from the bow of the fourth figure, who leaps through the air brandishing the weapon. Behind him, a snake or vine coils around a tall tuft of grass. Further down, a flower with leaves and/or thorns adorns the space following "words" in line 24. Right of the flower, a flying bird or insect appears to carry a snake through the air, recalling similar motifs on Plates 5, 15, and 19. Vegetable forms follow, with another large leaf or vine extending horizontally below line 26, lower left. Ornamenting the left margin are various other small-scale vegetative designs attached to letters.

In this copy, the form seems vegetative or worm-like.

At the end of line 2 near the right margin, a small figure sits with hunched shoulders on a vine. The figure faces left. It seems to hold an indeterminate object, perhaps a book or tablet. Thus, the figure may be reading or writing.
Various swirls and lines crossing at the end of line 2 suggest vines.

Following "falshoods" in line 5 is a hovering figure swathed in billowing garments. The swirls and folds of the garment appear vegetative in nature. The figure appears to be facing left and down, with one arm extended and perhaps pointing to the left.

Following "falshoods" in line 5 is a figure swathed in billowing garments. The swirls and folds of the garment appear vegetative in nature, and the figure is flanked by a small leaf-bearing branch on the left and flat, stylized leaves or ribbons on the right.

Following "notions" in line 9, two long, loopy vines—cf. a similar interlinear motif on Plate 15—radiate from a common center. The first four loops in the spiral on the right reverse the direction of those on the left.
Three leaves, the first of which is particularly vivid and broad, appear to the right of "further" in line 12.
Following "number" in line 17, three birds soar on extended wings. The bird on the far left has a particularly long, forked tail.

To the left of the long-tailed bird and below the smaller, nondescript bird at the end of line 17 are two swollen vegetable forms. A vine-like loop extending above the "h" of "he" at the end of line 18 coincides with the wing of the largest bird.

Four figures bound the plate's inscription, "A Memorable Fancy," on three sides in line 21. The first figure reclines beneath some leaves and branches to the left of the text. Like Ezekiel in Plate 13, this figure lies on its side, but—unlike the prophet—it faces the viewer with head resting on hand.

The first of four figures that ornament the space around the plate's inscription reclines beneath some leaves and branches to the left of the text. The vegetative canopy arches over the figure. The slope on which it lies is vine-like, becoming snaky—i.e., loopy and serpentine—as it clings to and climbs the left margin.

Above the inscription, "A Memorable Fancy," in line 21, the second figure hovers, facing right. Its legs are apart; one of them is extended backward and bent slightly at the knee. The figure's body is horizontal. Arm(s) outstretched, it seems to reach for the squiggly snake in front of it.
The hovering figure above the plate's inscription, "A Memorable Fancy," in line 21, seems to reach for the squiggly serpent in front of it. The serpent faces right; its mouth is open.

To the right of the plate's inscription, "A Memorable Fancy" (line 21), a nude male stands facing right with arms raised at 135 degrees. His hands are turned with palms facing up. The figure's head is bent back, and his legs are together; leaning backward, he appears to have just been impaled by the invisible arrow released from the bow of the fourth figure.

Facing the third figure who stands leaning slightly backward to the right of the plate's inscription, a nude figure leaps through the air brandishing a bow in its right arm. The left arm is drawn back. One leg is bent at the knee and extended backward.

The four-looped, spiraling vine growing from the "F" of "Fancy" in line 21 and the squiggly "y" of the same word continue the serpentine motif of the plate and the vignette. Behind the nude figure who leaps through the air brandishing a bow, a snake(?) or vine coils around a tall tuft of grass near the right margin of the plate.
Near the right margin of the plate and following the inscription, "A Memorable Fancy," in line 21, the form coiled around a tall tuft of grass might be a snake.
A flower with leaves and/or thorns adorns the space following "words" in line 24.

Next to the flower at the end of line 24, a bird or an insect flies on extended wings with a serpent or snake-like vegetation attached to it. The creature appears to be facing up. The motif recalls similar hybrids on Plates 5, 15, and 19.

Next to the flower at the end of line 24, a bird or an insect flies on extended wings with a serpent or serpentine vegetation attached to it. Two more vegetable forms follow; the second resembles a flaccid, swollen snake.
A large vine extends horizontally beneath line 26.

Ornamenting the left margin of the plate are various small-scale vegetative motifs, most of which are closely associated with letters, e.g., the leafy flourish off the "N" of "Now" in line 3 and the serpentine vines growing next to the "A" of "And" in line 6 and the "H" of "Have" in line 13. Vines or small leaves appear left of the first letters of the first words in lines 10 and 18.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A bearded nude male, looking out at the viewer with an expression of apprehension and dismay, crawls on hands and knees against a background that suggests gigantic tree trunks on the floor of a forest. The points of a crown can be seen on his head. This is apparently Nebuchadnezzar (not mentioned in the text), king of Babylon, enslaver of the Israelites, whose fall and exile are described in the apocalyptic Book of Daniel: "he was driven from men, and did eat grass as oxen, and his body was wet with the dew of heaven, till his hairs were grown like eagles' feathers, and his nails like birds' claws" (4:33). Beneath him is grassy ground and, as much a caption to the design as a final line of text, is a Blakean proverb: "One Law for the Lion & Ox is Oppression" (line 12).

illustration.illusobjdesc: At the top of the plate, following "rules" in line 2, a hunched-over figure sits with its head resting on its knees at one end of a serpentine vegetative motif. Completing the vignette is another figure striding along the wavy ascender of "the" in line 3. Its position and gestures are ambiguous: the figure possibly faces right, a scarf floating behind it. Alternatively, one might view the figure as facing left, grasping a disproportionally large scrolled shape; the design would then perhaps illustrate the angel of lines 3 and 4 "embracing the flame of fire." Next to "Elijah" at the end of line 5, a gowned figure hovers, facing left. A winged figure seen from behind hovers in the left margin between lines 5 and 6; vine-like forms appear to the right. A serried scene of five sundry figures—flanked by books on the right and more books, or possibly vegetation, on the left—also appears between the text of lines 5 and 6. Each of the figures sits or kneels. To the left of the first figure is an uncertain shape: possibly the profile of a horse or another figure. A small horse (minimally printed in this copy) leaps right above "world" in line 9. Following "well" at the end of the same line, a figure runs rightward, reaching for a vertical object which is more clearly a small child in other copies. The top half of the plate is dense with interlinear loops, vines, banners, and leaves, e.g., the vines and/or roots on either side of the figures populating the space between lines 5 and 6; the looped vines growing from the descender of "my" and the ascender of "friend," both in line 7; the elaborate curlicues following the text of line 11; and the small branch with spiky leaves extending from the "l" of "also" in line 10. Wing-like vegetable objects and/or soaring birds grace the plate—above "have" and "whether" in lines 9 and 11 respectively, for example. Blue tinting in the margins suggests sky.
